column1: Reviewed in the United States on November 18
Style: S20 FEColor: Cloud NavySize: 128GBVerified Purchase
I decided on the Samsung Galaxy S20 FE for my smartphone upgrade for a lot of reasons. One
column2: and most obviously
column3: was the price. At $599 ( the price on Amazon when I purchased it)
column4: it was an unbeatable deal. Another was the specs: Snapdragon 865 and 6gb of RAM was perfect for my needs. My old Galaxy S7 looked practically primitive when set against the S20 FE. And so
column5: I decided to give a midrange phone a try.

column2: the S20 FE seemed too good to be true. The screen
column3: while not 4K
column4: still looks great with the 120Hz refresh rate enabled. The rear cameras look incredibly good
column5: nice and crisp. I've done everything from web browsing and gaming to word processing and photography
column6: all with minimal issue. Battery life is solid
column7: but not the best in the market right now. You'll still be able to get a couple of days out of the S20 FE on 120Hz. Also
column8: you can't beat the customizability of Android. With the option to install launchers/widgets plus a wealth of storage (and SD card support)
column9: you get a lot of choice with the S20 FE. The size
column10: while much larger than I was used to
column11: still fits in the hand really well. I would recommend getting a case and screen protector for this one though
column12: as I have seen people shatter the screen with a single drop.

column2: if you've been reading up on the S20 FE at all
column3: then you know that there are problems. First off
column4: the virtual proximity sensor on the phone is spotty at best. Testing it out myself
column5: I had to be right on top of the sensor for it to detect my face. And for phone calls
column6: that means a few more accidental muted/ended calls than usual. The face recognition and fingerprint scanner are also not great. I'd say it works about 85% of the time
column8: do you ever feel it. Adding on
column9: the front-facing camera is pretty lackluster. Not bad
column10: but it's not flagship levels by any stretch. You'll need to be in absolutely optimal lighting to get a decent picture out of it. So if you're looking for a phone to take selfies indoors with

column2: the standout complaint with the S20 FE is the touchscreen. And yes
column3: my phone (ordered in early November) has the issue too. Pretty horrendous ghosting when testing it in the touchscreen test app. There's undeniably a hardware issue with the S20 FE. There have been updates since the phone released
column4: but none have fixed it entirely; merely a band-aid on a bloody gash. The real question is: does it affect everyday use? Will you notice it every moment you use the S20 FE? The answer to both is no
column5: at least for me. While I'm sure it does affect certain tasks (most notably those that involve fast touches or 3+ fingers)
column6: I really haven't noticed it in actual use. Pinching/zooming with your fingers close together will cause the screen to jitter
column7: but that's about all I've seen. If that worries you enough to pass on the S20 FE

column1: It really is a shame that I can't give the S20 FE a perfect 5 stars
column2: because it does deserve it in some aspects. But with these hardware issues
column3: there's always the worry that time will make them worse. It's a genuine worry
column4: I get that. But even with the problems
column5: the Samsung Galaxy S20 FE is a pretty great phone. It really does feel like a flagship phone
column6: but with a massive price cut and a few downgrades. Only time will tell if the problems the phone has will get worse
column8: I'm more than happy with it.

column1: Edit (8/18/2021): I've dropped my rating from 4 stars to 3 stars.
It's been a little less than a year
column2: and the issues mentioned above have started to affect daily use in a way that turns this from a great phone to an okay phone not worth your time. Okay
column3: maybe not daily use
column4: per se. But enough that it's starting to effect my initial thoughts on it.

column1: The amount of times this phone has turned on in my pocket because of ghost touches is insane. Every time I take it out of my pocket
column2: it's opened a random app and input a few letters on the keyboard. And this is after adjusting the settings to stop these sorts of things. I turned off double tap to turn on (despite wanting that feature) and turned on accidental touch protection (which did absolutely nothing). I even made it so that the phone needed face recognition or a fingerprint to unlock every time I close it. But it just keeps happening. No software update really fixed the screen
column3: as suspected. This is a pure hardware messup.

column2: honest truth: the screen on the S20 FE is terrible. Worse than my old S7. Worse than even a budget android phone's screen. It's beyond comprehension. The virtual proximity sensor is also worthless. I almost want to give it the classic "angry Amazon customer 1-star" review
column3: but I'll refrain. There's still good here with the chip
column4: customizability
column6: but that stuff can only get you so far.

column1: Here's my advice: don't bother with this phone. You can get a midrange smartphone for the same (or even a lower) price
column2: with better specs. It's still not the worst thing out there and I'm not tossing it in the trash just yet
column3: but it's definitely the last Samsung product I'll be buying. So disappointing
column4: but I couldn't keep this review a 4-star in good conscience.

column1: Reviewed in the United States on October 4
Style: S20 FEColor: Cloud NavySize: 128GBVerified Purchase
When I purchased this it was listed as 8gb of ram but the model I received is 6gb. That makes me feel lured into something I wasn't expecting.
The phone is a solid overall phone with premium performance for the price due to sacrificing the build quality by making the back plastic and the screen gorilla glass 3 instead of 6.
Doesn't matter to me as I wanted an unused device (battery) with a top notch processor for the smallest price point.
I'm still slightly upset about not getting 8gb as was listed when I purchased which is why I didn't rate 5/5.

Reviewed in the United States on October 22
Style: S20 FEColor: Cloud NavySize: 128GBVerified Purchase

This was the perfect phone until I started wondering what was wrong with my screen. Your touchs will be misread causing random inputs and jitter. This is a recording of how the phone is recognizing my inputs when using two fingers in alternating succession as well as when swiping with two fingers. This effects everyday use in subtle but frustrating ways. From taps being read as scrolling to unplayable multitouch games
column2: the screen makes me miss my 3 year old galaxy S8. The most recent software update to fix the issue has made no difference. If you buy this phone it WILL have this problem. I was originally in the group that assumed mine wasn't affected
column3: but it became hard to ignore the signs after a week.

column2: Not Sorry

column1: Great phone at a great price

column2: the day it came out. I got the Navy Blue

column5: but when I saw this phone in online comparisons and its 120hz screen
column8: that seemed like too good of a deal. While the OS is gussied up a bit from what's in the Pixel line
column9: it's not hard to figure out the differences and it adds a slight premium feel.

column1: The only negatives in comparison to the Pixel are the camera software isn't as good

column3: but I feel that the Pixel software doesn't add enough to the photos and that the extra cost gave me a phone with the kinds of features that will tide me over an additional year that the Pixel phones--with their weaker processors--likely would not. If anything else
column4: it should have decent trade-in value in a year or two.
